data.message: Hello TSP members! Many thanks to those of you who have done our first follow-up survey sent out two weeks ago. For those of you who haven't, don't forget to check your email and complete it for a $20 gift card! You’ll earn an additional $20 at the end if you fill out all surveys!

Just a friendly reminder to check your email and fill out the first follow-up survey that we sent out last week. Remember, you'll receive $20 for completing it and will receive an additional $20 at the end if you complete all follow-up surveys!

Hello TSP members! Today's post concludes our 90-day program. Please check your email today for our first follow-up survey. You will receive a $20 gift card upon completion.We hope that our Facebook group has been enjoyable, educational, and life-changing in some way, whether it be a shift in your perspective towards smoking, or a commitment towards a healthier, smoke-free life. All of us at TSP have enjoyed reading your comments and interacting with you online, and we truly thank you for your participation.Although we will no longer be posting daily, you are welcome to remain in this secret group and access all of the content we've shared over the past 90 days. Furthermore, we're still available to answer any questions/concerns about smoking, and we're open to any feedback/suggestions you may have for our program.Again, from all of us at TSP, thank you and good luck in your future endeavors!

#87: Ever wonder how much money you’ve spent on cigarettes? Use this Cost Calculator to see exactly how much you’ve spent and tell us what you would do with that money if you could get it back. #reflection http://buff.ly/1OqTlpY
it would take a chunk out of my tuition/debt for sure... seems to be around 6 grand
For the two years I've been smoking heavily I've spent just over 6,000 (according to this.)
I spent abt 30k.... Damn....... But a lot of Wht I've smoked I lifted off my uncle so I haven't "paid" that much.... I'd probably have a new car tho...
Thanks for giving this a try!
#84: How do you feel about a medication that changes its dose of nicotine to match the intensity of your withdrawal symptoms? Would you consider using varenicline? #beingconscious

It seems very interesting.  I personally wouldn't want to take it, but it looks like it works based on what I read.  If a person isn't concerned about taking a drug, I would recommend giving it a try.  The side effects don't seem that bad, apart from the off chance of it making you have suicidal thoughts.
Of the drugs I've read about it seems like it has a lot of potential to work well, especially because it can decrease the solace one may take in relapsing
It sounds sketchy, a pill that can change its dose??? Doesn't seem safe or possible
Thank you for sharing!
#79: What have you heard about bupropion to help people stop smoking? Would you consider taking a medication if it would help you successfully quit? #beingconscious
Bupropion, aka welbutrin, is an antidepressant. It would seem therefore that this drug should be used to treat a potential underlying cause of addiction, rather than marketed as a blanket remedy
I prefer to use as little medicine as possible. After seeing that it's an antidepressant, that makes me even less interested.
Nope nope nope.
Thanks for sharing - we appreciate your views!
#90: All federal buildings, many state and local government buildings, and even some parks, beaches and playgrounds are now smoke-free. What do you think of these laws? #smokingaffectsall
Its a good movement, but as I've said before, a lot of old smokers will ignore it
I don't think it deters people from smoking.

I don't see how they can ban smoking in an outdoor public area. If you're outside and not within around 5 ft of others it won't effect them. Idc if people don't want to see me smoking in public. I have that right as an American.
Indoors I completely understand though.
This is another repeat post. And again, laws banning smoking are reasonable (tho not necessarily effective) because smoking is a public health issue

#89: Instead of letting the health warnings about smoking go through one ear and out the other, let them sink in: COPD, lung disease, oral cancers, cataracts, the list goes on and on. How often do you think about these diseases when you smoke? #beingconscious
I'm a first year med student, which was the driving force behind me decision to quit. People truly suffer from the addiction.
I thought about a lot before I quit.
A lot going down the road to quitting
I think about it all the time.

#88: Research shows that one of the biggest triggers for smoking is stress. Familiarizing yourself with breathing techniques could help you relax without lighting up. Try this today when you feel stressed. Did it work? #feelinghealthy
Not much stress to be had today, unless graveyard shift at security is messed up tonight
Yes
These posts are getting repetitive. I know the difference between tension and relaxation.

#86: More and more states are raising the taxes on cigarettes. How do you feel about this as someone who smokes, and how do you feel when you think of yourself as a nonsmoker? Share your two different perspectives #smokingaffectsall
I feel as though nonsmokers either don't care or see it as an incentive for smokers to quit.  As a smoker, it just makes it harder for me to buy cigarettes.
Have you ever tried to quit or reduce your smoking? Which strategy did you choose and how did it go? #TDII

#85: When you think of yourself as someone who smokes, what words do you use to describe yourself? Pick one of these or add your own and tell us why that adjective fits your identity. #livinghealthy • Strong-willed• Thoughtful• Inconsiderate• Determined
Weak
Quitting certainly makes me feel strong willed and determined.
http://www.vice.com/read/quit-smoking-with-lsd-876?utm_source=vicefbus thoughts?

Very interesting article 10218! I think hallucinogens have great potential for helping people get over addictions. Check out this research at Johns Hopkins on magic mushrooms and smoking cessation: http://hub.jhu.edu/2014/09/11/magic-mushrooms-smoking I want to mention though that in these trials, the drugs themselves are a component of a larger treatment program and we certainly can't expect that everyone just has to pop mushrooms or LSD once and everything will be fine, but the research and the potential is definitely very exciting.
Haha, absolutely.  It did help me make that step to stop though, so when I found this I had to share

data.message: #83: Check out this slide-show to see how smoking affects your physical appearance as well as some things you can do to combat those consequences. Click through the slides and let us know what you think! #reflection
data.name: Slideshow: Surprising Ways Affects Your Looks
data.caption: www.webmd.com
data.description: Pictures of twins show how smoking dramatically speeds up wrinkles and aging. Also covered: sagging breasts, early menopause, hair loss, cataracts, infertility, and other effects of smoking.

data.message: I didn't know some of these could happen. The skin on my face is very unevenly toned so it's good to know why that could have happened.  I wonder if it will go back to normal.

#82: Many states and public organizations are offering free smoking cessation programs online like www.trytostop.org and www.smokefree.gov. How do you feel about these free resources as a smoker, and how do you feel as a potential nonsmoker? #smokingaffectsall
I've never used these resources, but I think it's wonderful that we have them.
I've tried Florida's but all they offer is toothpicks, mints, and very little "counseling"
#81: When you smoke, which one of these adjectives do you feel most often? If none of them fit you, add your own but be sure to share why! #livinghealthy • Controlled• In control• Restricted
Restricted.
Controlled
More of a relaxation
Relaxation
#80: When you don’t have a lot of time to de-stress, using this Countdown Relaxation technique can be a real life-saver. Would you use this strategy to avoid smoking? #livinghealthy
Absolutely
I don't have the attention span for meditation techniques but I appreciate their value
What is currently your biggest smoking trigger? #TDII
Eating a big meal and stress.
Hi 10218, these are common triggers that many people struggle with. What have you been trying to cope with these situations other than smoking a cigarette?
I've been "grounding" and meditating.
That's interesting! What do you mean by grounding?

I also use this technique for my ptsd: Grounding is a particular type of coping strategy that is designed to "ground" you in or immediately connect you with the present moment. Grounding is often used as a way of coping with flashbacks or dissociation. In this way, grounding can be considered a variant of mindfulness.Grounding techniques often use the five senses (sound, touch, smell, taste, and sight) to immediately connect people with the here and now.
Very cool 10218 - yes that does sound a lot like mindfulness. How successful were these strategies in helping you not smoke?
Very.  It's been rough but I'm 18 days clean!
The grounding works the best honestly.  It's helps me to get out of my repetitive and obsessive thoughts that come with my cravings.
That's great to hear 10218 - keep up the good work! I have another recommendation if you are into deep breathing and relaxation. You may want to give it a shot:
I will definitely do that.  I need to get into a daily routine of doing this.

#78: Ever notice the difference between the smokers in tobacco advertisements and the smokers you see in real life? Antonella did. Read her story and share with us anything you’ve noticed about Big Tobacco advertisements. #reflection
data.name: A Goodbye Letter to Cigarettes
data.caption: quitsmoking.about.com
data.description: Nicotine addiction is like a bad relationship. You know it's hurting you, but leaving it behind is tough. This goodbye letter was written by someone who found their way free of the destructive relationship...

data.message: I think it's the same as any form of advertisement, honestly.

I agree, the difference is in the product and not the ads. Beer companies don't look for girls with big guts to drink on TV, and tobacco companies don't look for their diseased customers to advertise.

#77: Anti-tobacco messages are being shown through news articles, commercials, movie/television characters, and of course, scientific reports. Do you think not smoking is becoming the new standard in our society? #smokingaffectsall
Well it has dropped within the past five years, so i'd say yes.
We no longer show major cultural support for the habit, and a lot of effort goes into fighting against the industry
Yes, very much so
#76: How do you view yourself when you smoke? Choose one of our options (or add your own) and tell us what makes you feel that way: Irresponsible, Independent, Responsible, Addicted. #knowyourself
Not in control, addicted, dirty
I feel irresponsible and addicted just because I know that what I'm doing is dumb
Addicted

data.message: #75: Meditation is a well-known relaxation technique that can be done anywhere - work, class, at home, ANYWHERE. Do you think this could help you avoid a cigarette? #livinghealthy
Its a possibility, but the hardest part for me would be trying to clear ur head, I got bad ADD... My mind runs 90-nothing while I sleep
It's pretty difficult to force yourself to meditate when you're in a situation that makes you want to smoke
I use it to help with cravings after I eat or in situations where I can separate myself.
I just never have time for anything
Meditation is a long process and takes alot of concentration focus and patience only few people can do, but I am going to try this
Thanks for sharing your thoughts! :)

#73: This over-the-counter Nicotine Replacement Therapy looks like cough drops and can help alleviate withdrawal symptoms during work or class. Would you be interested in trying this method? Why or why not? #beingconscious
Maybe if it didn't taste horrible like the gum.  It wouldn't work for me though; I had to stop using nicotine altogether.
Ive tried em, flavors don't last long, same as the gum
I'm not really looking to substitute one source of nicotine for another, I'm trying to eliminate my dependence on a crutch. So a gum or lozenge or patch is all kinda the same to me.
Thank you for sharing!
#70: Read about how smoking may have become a part of your self-image. How do you think about yourself as a smoker? Is smoking a part of who you are, or just something that you do? #knowyourself
I commented on this yesterday, Idk why it's not here.
It said "smoking was a part of my image."
Thanks for your comment, 10218! :)
#74: Creating a positive association with not smoking can keep you on the straight and narrow. What small rewards could keep you motivated if you experience withdrawal while quitting? #eyesontheprize
Being able to smell, being able to taste.
Spend more time with non smoking loved ones
No more wheezing, less coughing

#72: Liz writes about how her cravings may drive her nuts in the moment, but remembers that just because she wants to go back to smoking every now and then doesn’t mean her relapse is inevitable. After reading her letter, what are your thoughts on withdrawal symptoms? #reflection
data.name: I Will Survive! - A Goodbye Letter To Smoking
data.caption: quitsmoking.about.com
data.description: This letter from a forum member at About Smoking Cessation poignantly describes how nicotine addiction hurt other relationships in her life.

data.message: Just like any other drug, they can be overwhelming in the moment.  That's why it's so important to reinforce the long-term benefits to yourself, even when you're not having cravings.

#71: Have you heard? The World Health Organization is pushing for all countries to ban indoor smoking in public places and workplaces to protect nonsmokers from second-hand smoke. Are you glad that your parents, siblings, or children may be protected from toxins with this new ban? #smokingaffectsall
Yes.
Yes, its a good movement, but personally, bars and pool halls should be the exception
What do you guys like about smoking? #TDII
It helped with stress, I love the taste, and i liked that it was something to do. I enjoyed a cigar yesterday because I'm on vacation but apart from that I've been sticking to my vape.
Thanks for sharing 10218! It sounds like you purposefully smoked yesterday, but you are not planning to going back to it? What are you current plans for using your vape in the future?

Yes, i just smoked it because it was a special occasion.  I'm in Charleston with my family and my dad and I wanted to share a cigar on the beach.  I don't know what my plans are with my vape.  I really feel like it makes me want to smoke cigarettes.  When i use it to help with triggers it works well, but when I'm using it for boredom I just crave them.  I've been trying to stick to using it when I'm around other smokers because of that.

That sounds interesting 10218, so on the one hand your vape helps you to deal with cravings, on the other hand it can also produce cravings when you use it in different situations. Have you given any thought to things you could do when you are bored other than vaping? (sounds like these are your high risk situations)

Yes.  Usually scrolling through Facebook is enough, and when I'm at home doing my normal routine I can find things to do like draw or read, but I've realized that being on vacation is much different.  Lots of people smoke on the beach and pier as well as in front of restaurants and I have a lot of free time around that.  I've been boogie boarding and tanning as well as walking around the shops, but that only goes so far.

Sounds like you are in a somewhat unusual situation at the moment with plenty of smokers around and not all that much to do to keep you occupied. I wonder if there are other fun things you could do when you are bored? Reading, watching a TV show or a movie, listening to music, working out? What do you think?

I should sit on the beach and read my book.  Listening to music isn't all that helpful unless it's slow jazz or Bonobo, which/whom I love, but get tired of quickly. I'll give that a try as well.  Thanks for the tips, I was drawing a blank and desperately in need of distraction.

Sure anytime :) Maybe a combination of slow Jazz/Bonobo and reading when you get tired of the music is something that could work and distract you. Maybe you could also practice your drawing skills? The beach may not be the ideal location, but maybe worth a try?
I'm far enough away from the pier and it's late enough in the day that I don't have to be too worried about smokers.
Sounds like you're good for today! Tomorrow when it get's bad again and you hit a high risk situations try some of the strategies we have talked about today. It can't hurt to try, right?
Right!
Cool - I have to run. I'll talk to you next week. Enjoy your vacation!
Thanks :)
#69: Learning to keep calm when you’re stressed can help you avoid smoking. Try this relaxation technique today when you feel an urge to smoke. How did it go? #livinghealthy
Going to try it later, trying to start quitting/ cutting back immensely today
This just made me stop thinking about wanting a cigarette for the time it took me to do the exercise, but when I stopped I still wanted a cigarette.
Yea, same effect as 10194, just postponed the craving
Thank you for trying this out! :)
#66: When withdrawal symptoms are at their worst, a nasal spray can be a quick and convenient way to pack a punch to those cravings. Would you ever use a nicotine nasal spray? #beingconscious
I'd try it
That's just a classier way to rail a line to kill your cravings.
My nose is sensitive, so I don't think I'd be able to do it.  It's an interesting concept though.
It seems just like the gum or patch
Never tried it, I have actuallyn ever hear of it before, but I would be hesitant because I have sensitive allergies...
Thanks for sharing your thoughts!
#64: Some states are now banning smoking in ALL public places. How do you feel about the public effort to discourage smoking? #smokingaffectsall
I don't think it helps people not to smoke.  It only makes it more inconvenient for a smoker.  If they really want to smoke they'll do it.
Exactly. I've walked 100yrds from a hospital that had no smoking for 1/2 of one AS A PATIENT
It does help rally non smokers against the habit by marginalizing those who smoke. Non smokers appreciate the lack of smell
Thanks for sharing your view!

#67: Thoughts about smoking don’t just disappear when you decide to quit. Be ready when those thoughts hit. Choose one of the following strategies that might help you stay focused on quitting. Why would it work for you? #eyesontheprize • Get up and do something active• Find a healthy way to relax or deal with the stress in your life • Keep your hands busy• Think about something else!
Apart from using my ecig, which I'm using less and less, I've been chewing gum.

#65: Here’s a story of James, a 22-year-old man who quit smoking after starting before he was even 15. Tell us if his Quit Letter inspired you to find new reasons to quit or to reach out to someone else close to you who is trying to do the same. #reflection
data.name: A Diagnosis of Cancer Helped James Quit For Good
data.caption: quitsmoking.about.com
data.description: A diagnosis of cancer at the age of 20 was the final straw that helped James decide to quit smoking for good.

data.message: I'll certainly be talking about this to my younger friends who smoke.

Did you know that you can avoid almost all of the negative long-term health consequences of smoking if you quit before you are 30 years old? Does that change how you feel about smoking and quitting? #TDII
My ex always said that and used it as an excuse to smoke.  He's turning 30 this year though and he still smokes.  I feel like it's a good reason to quit early.
Yes, I agree 10218 - feel free to check out this chart to remind you of the benefits of quitting.
I've got to run - check out this study if you're interested http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMsa1211128
Makes me want to quit smoking sooner

Finally bought my vape pen.  Similar but different than an ecig, this has adjustable wattage (max 30 watts but I keep it at 20).  The juice has three or four ingredients:  propylene glycol, vegetable glycerin, flavoring, and nicotine if you want it (I chose to get 0 nicotine.) what are your thoughts?  I'd like everyone's opinion. Do you have these where you're from?
People love these in NYC, the flavors are actually pretty nice
Is that the eleaf 30w?
Yes, yes it is.
I got the 50w.... I like them, best thing to do is get an RDA and high VG fluid, u can make ur own coils to produce how u want but u need a minimum 50w to make good coil

I'm not really in to making my own coils.  I just want something to smoke that's not nearly as harmful as a cigarette.  Apparently it's a really common thing to do though because I hear about people doing that a lot.  What kind of difference does it make?
U can make ur coils to produce more clouds, more flavor, or a happy medium
I see.  Interesting

#63: Remember the small steps towards quitting from a few weeks ago? Let’s try another! Choose one that you haven’t tried before, and tell us how it went. #freeyourself • Delay your first cigarette of the day by 10 minutes• Limit your smoking to one or two places only • Smoke fewer cigarettes each day• Quit smoking for 24 hours
Currently 3 days cigarette-free.  I've had a few here and there since I decided to quit, but it was because I was drinking.  Perhaps I'll have to try one of these techniques then.
I can try to limit the places

#62: Imagine you’re an executive for a large tobacco company who's been asked by a child to present at her school on Career Day. What would you say about your company’s mission? What would you tell the kids about smoking? #knowyourself
The mission is to make money, and the companies already have tobacco farms, so selling tobacco is pretty logical. Smoking, on the other hand, is illogical and should be avoided.
I agree, u CNT tell a 3rd grader to buy tobacco....
Now that would be embarrassing... for many.. I'm not sure there is a good way of explaining it to a child, it would be similar trying to explain alcohol...

I think the most important thing for that person in the situation to do above all else is stress the point that this is for adult only. My mother used to call alcohol "Mommy Juice" and "only mommies can drink it after a hard day's work" and I never had an interest in drinking until I was a teen and heard otherwise (It did kinda blow my mind at first that there were middle school kids drinking though) So I guess you could say that strategy works pretty well. At least it did for me
I agree with 10194.
I would probably try to avoid talking about the tobacco and more about the industrial stuff and what my job involves.

data.message: #60: Smoking can touch virtually everyone in your life. If you choose to quit smoking, how would the lives of the people closest to you change in response to your decision? What chain reaction would you set off? #smokingaffectsall

^straight up, my quitting has brought mad attention to my friends' habits. Happy 4th everybody!
Less smoking amongst my friends
That's great to hear! We hope you all had a fantastic fourth of July!

#59: It’s time to turn over a new leaf. Collect all the things in your house that remind you of smoking (lighters, matches, ashtrays, your stashed away emergency pack) and replace them with your list of reasons to quit. Take a before-and-after pic and post it here! #eyesontheprize
Before
After
LOVE THIS! Thanks for sharing this, 10218! :)
#58: Make a list here of all your pros for quitting smoking. How many can you think of? #balance
Saving money, improving my health, and avoiding social stigma is mostly it
Pros:-i can breathe better-i can smell-i don't smell like cigarettes-i've already saved well over 100 dollarsCons-none at this point
Awesome lists!

#57: Statistics show that the most successful smokers use a combination of Nicotine Replacement Therapy (like the patch or gum) with some type of counseling to quit, but young adults are the least likely to use NRT’s to quit. Would you ever consider using an NRT? What about counseling to help you quit? #beingconscious
Quite frankly I quit on my own when I was ready.  NRT's didn't do it for me.
Counseling hasn't helped in the past, not even from a doctor.... And patches haven't effected me at all. The gum would deliver some nicotine but Tue flavor was unbearable
Nrt's helped mesquite for a brief period. I didn't keep up on them and eventually broke down and started smoking again.
Counseling maybe, but first hand stories from smokers that have holes in there throat and so on would open my eyes
I think NRTs are only good for people who aren't really ready to quit and need to ease into it a little more. I think counseling could be helpful if you're receptive to it
I think talking to a therapist who actually cares about helping you will help you overcome any addiction honestly
Thank you so much for discussing! :)

#61: Having a motivating and centering mantra that you can repeat to yourself when things get tough can be a HUGE help to deal with cravings. Think of your own mantra/phrase you could use when cravings hit hard, and post it here. #feelinghealthy
I try to remind myself that it's never worth it to cave. I always regret it.
Die 7mins sooner....
One more day.  (I'm taking it a day at a time)
How does your smoking affect your loved ones, kids, or significant other? What do they think about your smoking? #TDII
They hated the fact that I smoked but they knew they couldn't stop me.
Thanks for sharing 10218! So at one point you decided on your own that you wanted to. How are you holding up?
I've got to run - see you next week!
Damn it I always forget to check these.
#56: Take a look at Christine’s story and share your thoughts about how smoking has forever changed her life and the way she nourishes herself. #reflection http://buff.ly/1IevQ3v
data.name: Christine - Feeding Tube
data.caption: www.youtube.com
data.description: Christine talks about what it's like to live with oral cancer, from eating through a tube to still having some hope. Watch her video and get to know her a li...

data.message: It seems like some/a lot of what she's dealing with is from chemotherapy/radiation.  Of course she had to deal with that because of her oral cancer, but there were other, less destructive forms of treatment she could have chosen.  It doesn't surprise me that she got cancer again, considering how common recurrences are with chemo.  It's considered a successful treatment if your cancer doesn't come back for 5 years.  Not forever.  Cancer is still very difficult to treat and doctors tend to push chemo/radiation for varying reasons, mostly because it's the "most successful."  Overall, this video is misleading.  Also, as mentioned in the last video like this, extreme cases aren't very convincing to smokers.
Thank you for sharing your views!
#55: Who are you a role model for? Siblings, children, nieces, nephews? How would their lives change if you decided to quit? #smokingaffectsall
I'm the youngest, but my brother and sister would be really happy if I quit my older brother did and always tries to encourage and help me quit
I'm sure neither of my siblings knows I've ever smoked but they're both younger and would probably be extremely upset
My little brother already smokes. I feel like it's because he's seen me do it. So maybe if I quit I can encourage him.
My younger sister looks up to me but hated that I smoked.  She's so happy that I've stopped.
#54: Bars and restaurants across the country are banning smoking. Is it legal to smoke in restaurants or bars in your state? How does it affect you? #smokingaffectsall

Here in ohio smoking in public buildings is completely banned.  Though, some places have been grandfathered in for being there for so long.  there's one tobacco shop I'm my town that smoking inside is allowed and legal
It's illegal in NYC too
It's illegal to smoke in any building in IL except designated smoke shops.  It makes it much more enjoyable at restaurants.
It's illegal to smoke pretty much anywhere in CA
Illegal in public buildings and within 25 feet of one in Michigan but then again we have a hookah lounge we can smoke hookah and cigarettes inside
Thanks so much for sharing and knowing your laws! :)

#51: Smoking can feel “automatic,” but sometimes situations arise that make us want to smoke more. Which of these are triggers for you? #beingconscious • When you’re feeling impatient • When you need a break• When you’re bored• When you’re watching TV
Break and post meal
Boredom, impatience, and needing a break are all huge
On my break at work sometimes or after work.
Thanks for identifying your triggers -- knowing them may be helpful in altering your smoking habits when you are ready to.

#52: A private jet, glamorous jewelry, fancy nails, and of course an e-cigarette. How many ways do you see Blu trying to sell their product as something that will make you fancier, richer, and more sophisticated? Their master plan isn’t so under-the-radar! #ecig

The whole image is designed to make you feel as though using blu e-cigs make you elegant.  I could probably sit here and count all the things but it would take too long.  I will point out, however, that if these are the e-cigs you guys are studying and using for comparison, I don't think you're using the right kind.  Of course those are horrible.  You should be studying the vape pens that are so popular.  They use 3 or 4 ingredients in their juice. Or at the very least, don't lump the two together.
Exactly as 10218 put it, it is supposed to make u feel it is a gate way to elegance...
Great points, you guys!
#49: What have you heard about nicotine gum? Do you think the gum will help you? #beingconscious
It tastes disgusting, it tightens my throat, it makes me sick.  I can't use it
I've never tried it.  Wanted to but thought it would be nasty.
It is.  Lol.
I've never tried it.
I've never tried it, and since the oral fixation is such a big part of smoking for me I thought it would be nice, but if it tastes like ass I'm not down.
I'm not saying don't give it a try, just be aware.
Haha I appreciate that, but thanks for the heads up!
Doesn't sound very helpful, its just gum
Tried it, hate the flavors
Thanks for discussing! :D
#48: Gruen never thought he’d be living with cancer before he was even 18 years old.  Watch this and share your thoughts. #reflection
data.name: Gruen - Cancer at 17
data.caption: www.youtube.com
data.description: Gruen was diagnosed with cancer when he was 17 years old. He tries to make the best of it, though, spending time with his daughters and ignoring people's sta...

data.message: I mean, Yea, its a lesson learned, but truth is, anything has the capabilities of causing cancer, especially these days

I live in central Illinois as well.  It could have been a combination of the tobacco and the extreme use of pesticides on our crops (especially because he was in a small town and was most likely surrounded by fields or corn or soybeans.)
Sensationalized cases tend not to have a huge impact on my thought process. I already know that smoking causes cancer, showing statistical anomalies this way seems contrived.
Thank you so much for watching and discussing.

data.message: #53: If you labeled yourself as a nonsmoker, how would your self-image change? How would you see yourself differently if you no longer smoked? #knowyourself
I quit for a while in January and nothing changed. My self image was the same, I just wasn't smoking.
I probably wouldnt be as ashamed.
I feel a lot of guilt about the habit that I could do well without.
It's a person I dont think I am capable of being
At least not now my life is a mess

#50: One thing you can try when your cravings get bad is call someone you trust and tell them that you’re trying not to smoke. Try this instead of giving in to your cravings, and tell us if it worked for you. #feelinghealthy
I prefer to talk face to face.  I just complain about it to whoever's around me.
This seems like one of those ideas that only makes sense to people that don't smoke
Yea there isn't always someone available and not only that but they don't wanna listen to someone talking about that
I know stopping smoking is not easy. How confident are you that you could quit smoking if you tried? #TDII

I decided to quit last week and I've only had one since then.  I've been usi ng vape pens when they're around but only becausw they're much safer.  Not perfect, but much better.  There are only 3 ingredients in the juice and the wick is 100 percent organic cotton.
10218 it's great that you stopped smoking cigarettes almost entirely! That's a big success and you can be proud of yourself! Do you already know how you want to use your ecig in the future?
It'll probably just for social events or when I'm drinking.

I was just asking because also ecigs are not without risk and may potentially still be harmful for your health (even though most likely way less harmful than regular cigs). We simply don't know enough about them yet, and they are not regulated by the FDA, so we also can't be entirely sure what's in them. I just want to give you my reasons why I can't recommend their use 100%. I'll keep checking in with you over the next couple of weeks to see how your quitting is going. But for now: Great job!
Thank you :)
I've got to run. Talk to you next week!

#47: According to the CDC, 126 million nonsmokers are exposed to second-hand smoke, and the most exposure occurs in vehicles and homes. Who may have inhaled smoke in your car or home? #smokingaffectsall
My fiance
My ex and my friends.
Friends, try not smoke around people that don't or don't like it

data.message: I mean its propaganda just like media on wars, we have no way of knowing if its true or if its actors... So I don't really trust it
I think it does help people not to start smoking, but I don't think ot helps smokers to quit.
Thanks for watching! :)
I can't watch this my son died of SIDS
I still think it's my fault because I smoked 2 cigs per day while breast feeding I never did it anywhere near him but obviously it's my fault
I'm not okay right now sorry
10255, we are so sorry for your loss. <3
#44: What are some of your favorite qualities about yourself? How does smoking fit (or not fit) with that image of you? #balance
I'd like to believe that I'm a smart guy, but smoking is certainly not a smart habit.
Well I was always so stubborn about smoking outside I was a cigarette in my mouth........ But not anymore since I quit

My best features are my intelligence and and my musical talent. I play the cello and the guitar and can pick out a tune on just about anything.  I used to sing but I stopped when it became difficult to breathe.  I agree with what 10194 said.
I've never really liked myself. Probably why I started smoking anyway. I started to like myself when I was a mother but of course I messed that up too
Thank you for sharing your favorite qualities! :)
#46: Lots of smoker's report that they smoke more often when they're stressed. What can you do differently to deal with daily stressors in your smoke-free future? #balance
Go to the gym
I've been taking deep breaths and reminding myself of my intentions
I try to rationalize not smoking because ruining my quitting spree will stress me out even more

#45: Remember that small step towards quitting you chose 2 weeks ago? Try out a different one and tell the group how it worked out for you. #freeyourself • Delay your first cigarette of the day by 10 minutes• Limit your smoking to one or two places only • Smoke fewer cigarettes each day• Quit smoking for 24 hours

I'm currently 23 hours in to quitting.  I ran out yesterday and made the push not to buy a new pack.  I'm already irrational and bitchy and I occasionally get jittery.  I just keep reminding myself that this is temporary and that it's worth it.
Besides a few drunken missteps I haven't relapsed yet
Well I been without for almost a a week and a half now
Hi guys, I'm back from my trip. How have you been and what's your current smoking status? #TDII
Up to smoking a pack a day.
Thanks for sharing 10218! How do you think about quitting at the moment?
I want to, I hate being out of breath, I'm just so stressed all the time.

Sure, I understand. Stress is a big time trigger for many people I work with. We can try to come up with alternatives to smoking that can help with stress reduction. What else could you do when you are stressed out?

Well I often resort to eating when I don't want to smoke, but I know that's not a good habit either.  Working out only helps so much because I love to smoke after I work out.  The most productive thing for me is waiting 5 minutes to smoke.  Quite often it ends up being half an hourm
Waiting is a great strategy, 10218! Good job. We can work more on additional strategies over the next weeks!
Sounds good!
Sorry, I've got to run. I'll check in with you next week. See ya!
#42: Has smoking changed the way you view yourself? What is your self-identity as someone who smokes? #knowyourself
I don't feel different about myself. Maybe should, maybe it would help me quit.
My smoking habits are a constant reminder of my horrible past.  I think it's the last thing i need to let go of in order to show who I am on the inside.
Being an addict makes me feel weak. I appreciate my independence.
Being an addict makes me feel weak. I appreciate my independence.
I feel my stamina decrease but that may also be age
Thank you for sharing.

#41: Think about when, where, and why you choose to smoke when you do. Do those situations have in anything common? Pick one of the following situations (or tell us your own) and tell us why that circumstance almost always ends with a cigarette for you. #beingconscious • When you’re drinking coffee• When you’re driving• When you’re drinking alcohol• When you’re talking on the phone• When you’re feeling down
Dealing with idiots at work....
I always light up a cigarette when I get in the car, partially put of habit, partially because I enjoy smoking in my car

I can't drink coffee anymore because it's such a trigger. I think a lot of it has to do with the synergy of caffeine and nicotine, but also the effects both smoking and drinking coffee after a meal have on digestion
Driving, I'll smoke like 5 in a row and something to do while driving along with being in a big group of new people it gives me something to do and relieves anxiety
Working

data.message: #38: What have you heard about the patch, a form of Nicotine Replacement Therapy? Would you ever use it? #beingconscious
Tried, no help

Personally I think it makes it a lot easier to quit. I was able to make it through days at a time with no cigarettes, using the patch. It wasn't higher dose patch, but I wasn't at everyone's throat around me.
Never tried it, but next to ecigs and gum it seems less likely to be satisfying.
Haven't tried it.  I've heard it's helpful.
It made my boyfriend really sick when he tried it.
Thank you for sharing!
#37: With all the new Tobacco Legislation, most workplaces are now smoke-free. Do you think it's better for society as a whole to have smoke-free workplaces? #smokingaffectsall
It helps but smokers will go right off the property and smoke twice as much
I think smokers should have a right to smoke at their workplace.  I don't think it makes people smoke less.  It just makes it more difficult
Both are valid points, also with banned smoking at a workplace a worker could grow agitated over the smallest of things.
I do not think smokers should have the right to smoke in the workplace when it has been shown that secondhand smoke is dangerous. Besides, it's very rare that non smokers appreciate the smell
It depends on if it's on site or in a designated area away from others
I think there should be designated areas, not just running amuck smoking wherever they please at work.
I like the smoking area. They should be quickly accessable so someone can use their ten or fifteen minute break without any problems
Thank you so much for discussing! :D
#36: Check out how one Tobacco company called young adult smokers "replacement smokers" on record. What does it feel like to be part of a big, expensive marketing strategy? #reflection
It feels shitty to know that I was sucked in.
Well I mean all people are these days is part of a marketing strategy, every aspect of our lives is a marketing strategy
This may have been more stressful in the past but we sign away our souls to big corporations on a regular basis
It's extremely lame and inhumane
Great points, everyone! :)
#40: How do you think your home environment would change if you quit smoking? #beingconscious
It would be a smoke free home.
My home already is smoke free
My backyard wouldn't have butts everywhere.
The ashtray was an unfortunate necessity before I quit, now I don't have a bowl of soot on the table
The ashes are irritating on clothing and on the ground. I don't like when people ash and leave a big black mark on the pavement

#39: Children can’t really distinguish between vapor and smoke. What they see are important adults in their life setting an example for how to take care of themselves, what they spend their money on, and their attitudes about addictive substances. Would you hide your e-cig smoking from a child? #ecig
Always do
I would never lie to my child, but I wouldn't smoke next to him/her even if it is an ecig.
I always avoid vaping or smoking in front of kids.

Hi Everyone, I am switching things up and doing The Doctor Is In a bit later this week. What are people dealing with this week? Has anyone in this group tried to quit smoking? If so, how did it go? If not, what is getting in your way?

I like to leave you guys with tips in these session, so today, here is our 5-step TSP quit plan. See if something resonates with you: 1. GET READY.• Set a quit date and stick to it – not even a single puff! 2. GET SUPPORT AND ENCOURAGEMENT.• Tell your family, friends and coworkers you are quitting.• Talk to your doctor or other health care provider.• Get group, individual, or telephone counseling. Think about who can support you with quitting smoking3. LEARN NEW SKILLS AND BEHAVIORS.• When you first try to quit, change your routine.• Reduce stress.• Distract yourself from urges to smoke.• Plan something enjoyable to do every day.• Drink a lot of water and other fluids. Think about which of these will be most helpful to you?4. GET MEDICATION AND USE IT CORRECTLY.Talk with your health care provider about which medication will work best for you:• Medication: bupropion, verenicline (prescription).• Nicotine Replacement:-gum and patch are over-the-counter-inhaler and nasal spray are prescriptionIs there one of these that you think would be helpful for you?5. BE PREPARED FOR RELAPSE OR DIFFICULT SITUATIONS.• Avoid alcohol.• Be careful around other smokers.• Improve your mood in ways other than smoking.• Eat a healthy diet and stay active.
Thanks for this ^ it seems like a wonderful plan.
#35: When you read this statistic, who in your life do you start thinking about? Friends, family, coworkers? #smokingaffectsall
My family.
Everyone around me. Itry my best to stand away from others, especially nonsmokers
I think of my boyfriend.
I never smoked much around non smokers, but I guess this stat makes me feel kind guilty
Same as 10194, most people around me smoke
#34: Let's see how many comebacks you guys can come up with for this ever-popular drawback to quitting. What will you tell yourself if this thought crosses your mind? #balance

It appears that our past posts have disappeared, but we expect them to be restored soon. In the meantime, we'll be manually sharing our daily post so that you can continue commenting. We apologize for any inconvenience. Thanks for bearing with us! :)-Shirley from TSP
Gaining weight isn't as bad as getting lung cancer.You can lose the weight again.  You're not stuck with it.
Always ways to lose it, work out and eat healthy while trying to quit
It looks like we're back up! Don't worry about the duplicate post -- feel free to comment on either one. Thank you!-Shirley from TSP
Weight gain isn't on my issue list

data.message: #34: Let's see how many comebacks you guys can come up with for this ever-popular drawback to quitting. What will you tell yourself if this thought crosses your mind? #balance
I don't have a problem with weight

#25: Take a few deep breaths to center yourself the next time your cravings are getting to you. Try it out today and tell us how it went. Were you able to put off lighting up for a little while? #feelinghealthy
Slow, deep breaths can help ease the headaches quitting has given me... but only barely
They don't seem to be helpful to me
I've found what works for me is to keep busy. The idle moments are the smoking ones

I thought I commented on this, but my phone has been acting up.  I said I use these types of breathwork for focusing and relaxing as well as meditating.  It makes sense that this would help, and it did!
Thanks for trying it out! :)

#24: Big Tobacco is advertising e-cigarettes as a safer and better way to smoke, but studies have shown that they still contain toxins. Why do you think so many people are ready to adopt them even before proper research has been conducted? #ecig

Cheap ecigs have lots of toxins in them.  You can find ecig juice that has only three or four ingredients.  When I'm off work I'll post some examples.  And to answer your question, most people are uninformed consumers.
Propoganda
E cigs seem safer on an intuitive level because vaporization produces fewer byproducts than combustion. The vapor looks and feels healthier than smoke
Smoke is known to be carcinogenic
http://www.virginvapor.com/collections/organic-e-liquid/products/10ml-3-pack-sampler-virgin-vapor-line this is just one example.
Thanks so much for discussing! :)

#20: Part of the new Tobacco Legislation is that physicians and clinicians must encourage and help their smoking patients quit. Do you think help from a health professional would motivate you to quit? #smokingaffectsall
I hate when my doctor tells me to quit.  So no.
A lot of people hate the doc so they probably wont

I agree with above posts, the problem with doctors nowadays is it's not personal enough. I get the feeling that they don't know what I'm going through, and they don't approach it effectively because of that
I think a therapist is more helpful in quitting.
Agreed ^
Thanks for sharing your opinions!

#33: Social situations can make it hard to not smoke, especially when alcohol is involved. Does alcohol affect your smoking? How would you change that if you wanted to cut down or quit? #beingconscious
Alcohol make me feel the need to smoke a lot more, packs within hours. But I don't really drink much so I usually don't have to worry about that.
I will have to cut back on my drinking.  Right now I feel as though if I only smoke when I drink I'll be fine.  The only problem with this is that I drink quite often.
The real problem is that smoking while drunk feels super awesome, and drunkenness really hurts the will to abstain.

#32: It’s not just your friends and family who may want you to quit! The Surgeon General’s office, the Center for Disease Control (CDC), and other national organizations are urging people to quit smoking. How does it feel to see our society moving towards a tobacco-free mindset? #smokingaffectsall

I think it's awesome how effective the commericals I see are.  They're using techniques that many other commercials use to promote their products.  I don't know why they didn't start doing that sooner
Its a great movement, but it seems more directed to the population that hasn't been smoking for more than a few yrs, older smokers are more reluctant to quit because it is part of them
#31: Turn it up a notch. Tell someone special about the small step you tried yesterday. How did it go? #freeyourself
My mom said "woohoo!  So proud of you!"

#30: Baby steps are required to conquer smoking once and for all. Pick one of these small steps to try and post your choice here. #freeyourself• Smoke five fewer cigarettes each day• Delay your first cigarette of the day by 10 minutes• Limit your smoking to one or two places only • Quit smoking for 24-hours
I'm doing the last one, quitting smoking for 24 hours at a time. It'll be 2 weeks on Sunday :/
Quitting for 24 hours sounds tough, but worth the effort.  I'll start by cutting back.
Limited smoking areas
Done all of the above before and they are methods that work effectively. From there is just a mental thing of keeping it up. Discipline
I wait a couple hours after waking up to smoke it helps
I think doing the "the doctor is in" events later in the day or having two events would be better.  One at 4 or 5 and one at 8 or 9.  Does anyone else agree with me?

Thanks 10218 I'm happy to switch it up next week and see if soothing a bit later can work. We're all on different timezones, so each time will be good for some people and not so good for others. But we aim to please so will try to make this service avail for the most people. See you next week!
See you then!

I want to leave you guys with a post about visual imagery that can help if you are having cravings to smoke and don't want to (or can't). As an experiment this week, try this and see if it can be helpful to you.
Hi Everyone, I'm here for the next hour to answer any questions or chat about smoking and quitting. What have been your biggest triggers to smoke lately?
#29: Hoping to be prepared for withdrawal symptoms? Learn about what to expect here and tell us how you’re planning to deal with these symptoms when you decide to quit. #balance
I recently quit, the headaches were unreal for a week
I'm honestly unsure of how to prepare

First, I'll talk to the people around me and tell them that I'm quitting.  I'll ask them to be prepared for these things; to help me and be understanding.  I plan on using meditation and exercise to help fight these symptoms.
Sometimes it's due to the withdraw symptoms that I cancel my quitting because I don't have the time or space to experience the symptoms and get thru it... school and work and life

data.message: #28: In a survey of 800 New Yorkers:• 81% agreed that most people would not hire a smoker to take care of their children• 72% agreed that most non-smokers would be reluctant to date a smoker• 39% agreed that most people think less of a person who smokes• 21% agreed that most people think smoking is a sign of personal failure What do YOU really think of smokers when you see them on the street? #knowyourself
I don't think any different of them, but I judge no one by how they appear
I automatically assume they are from a lower class or have been through a lot of struggles (like myself.)  Even though I smoke, I still judge others who smoke.
I don't judge them, I just wonder how their health feels
I think people smoke for lots of reasons and I can't really judge because i smoked for so long myself
Thank you for sharing!
#27: If you want to get info about how to quit smoking, where do you go? How do you know the source is true? #beingconscious
I would use programs offered through my school, which are trustworthy.
I'm not sure I would go anywhere, everyone's experience is different so not everyone can b treated the same

#26: Studies of former smokers show that it is extremely helpful to know where, when, and why you are most likely to smoke. That way, when you’re quitting your habit, you can plan ahead for those situations and won’t be caught off guard. Which situation are you most likely to smoke in? #beingconscious • When you first wake up in the morning• When you’re stressed• When you’re socializing with friends• When you’re tired• When you’re in a bad mood
All except socializing. I smoke because I've formed an addiction as well as a habit. Not to impress anyone.
Stressed, socializing, driving, and after I eat are the big ones.
When I first wake up for work, if I could get a Dr. Notice telling me not to do that, I would be very happy
I smoked in all of those circumstances but the morning cig with coffee made getting up a lot easier
Agreed on the driving and the stress....

#23: Breathing and relaxation techniques can be really helpful when you quit and enrich your daily life. Here’s a link describing a few different techniques -- try one out and tell us how it went. Which one works best for you? #feelinghealthy http://quitsmoking.about.com/od/cravingsandurges/a/deepbreaths.htm

I use the first one mentioned - holding your tongue to the front roof of your mouth and breathing in through the nose and out through the mouth - quite often when I'm trying to relax.  It works very well
I've used distractions like easing the car in the past and that seemed to help

#22: It’s no shock that tobacco companies spend loads of time and money thinking of how to appeal to a younger crowd with fresher lungs. Check out this document, straight from a major tobacco company. How does it feel to be targeted by a huge, expensive marketing campaign? #beingconscious
It's crazy how much goes into marketing and how much research they do on human behavior and especially how darn successful they are
It doesn't surprise me, seeing as it's done by many major companies, not just big tobacco. It's disgusting, but not shocking.
I do marketing so its no surprise
It makes me extremely uncomfortable but I think it's an aspect of corporate America, not just tobacco. Lots of industries market and lobby on a massive level.
Gross. 'm curious to see what American Spirits say though

Hi Guys, I am doing The Dr Is In sessions today instead of Johannes Thrul. I am an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at UCSF in San Francisco and creator of TSP. Happy to answer any questions you have - I'm here for an hour. Is anyone trying to quit in this group?
Yes! I posted on the picture in the event asking what you thought was the best reason to quit
Hi there! You found me here ;) The best reason to quit is whatever it is to you. What's your top reason to quit? It's definitely better if it is personal.
I'm always out of breath and I worry about my health overall.  i also recently found out that it's especially dangerous to smoke while taking birth control and that it can cause heart problems.

Yes, that is true. Smoking while on birth control is a risk factor for stroke. It is a very important (and personal) motivator to quit. Are you feeling ready to set a date to quit? If so, we can help you to prepare for it.
If we set a date, i feel as though it would have to be a month or more in advance.  I'm also worried that I might give up.
That's ok. If you decide to set a date, a month or more is fine. The way we handle it here is that if you want we can schedule you an event for it and talk in these sessions about how to get ready.
What specifically would that involve?
We can also talk about it in more detail next week.  I know we started late.

Our quit plans have five steps: 1. set a date, 2. tell people you know that you are quitting, 3. learn new skills and behaviors to support quitting, 4. get medication and use it correctly, and 5. be prepared for difficult situations.

So to start, we recommend people set the date, and then preparing for that date, we talk about telling people, and sometime also reducing the number of cigarettes you smoke. right before the date, we suggest getting rid of all smoking paraphernalia. Even matches/lighters/ashtrays. EVERYTHING!

Yes, we did - my fault. Happy to support you in starting the process though setting a date. I will be here for the net two weeks as well. Think about when you might like to quit and then see if you would be willing to share it here and maybe with someone else in your life.
Gotta run, but I will be here two more weeks and we can follow-up on anything else you are thinking about or questions before Johannes Thrul is back. Great chatting today!

I will get a very serious health condition or cancer
Dealing with the mood changes. I quit for 3 weeks in January and it seemed to have me in edge for the first 2 weeks.
I want to quit smoking but I'm afraid of the overwhelming stress, I been smoking for yes and gotten used to the stress relief, and working almost 17hrs 6days a week, the stress is a huge concern
I want to quit smoking but I'm afraid the stress will be too much.
Mostly stress and weight gain
I am worried about the depression and being around people who smoke

#19: Who’s that one friend you can count on to listen to you when you need it? Who will you be able to trust as your supporter when you are ready to quit smoking? #support
My fiancee
My roommate, who also smokes but not as much and would like to quit
My boyfriend.
My boyfriend
#17: All change has pros and cons. What are some of the cons of quitting smoking? Why might it be hard for you to quit? #beingconscious
I use it as a stress reliever, addicted to the motions of putting a cigarette to my lips and it helps my mood
Increase on stress levels
Stress, anxiety, the constant cravings.
I smoke cigarettes ritualistically. When I wake up, after a big meal, in between classes, etc. Now there are holes in my day where i miss smoking very much.
Stress and depression, anger and bitter grief make it extremely difficult for me to quit. A lot of times I have quit it was due to those emotions that I went back to it.

#16: Quitting can help preserve our planet! Without cigarette smoke, the chances of household fires decrease and less secondhand smoke is released into the air we breathe. Can you think of any other environmental improvements that might result from less smoke?
Air quality, and litter from cigarette butts
I'm sure tobacco processing plants have a negative impact on the environment.
The two biggest impacts i can think of would probably be less cigarette butts and less harm from the proccessing plants. ^
Less cigarette buts
Less butts and less smoke
Have you ever noticed a connection between smoking and your mood? Is there an emotional state that gets you to light up more frequently? #TDII
When I'm stressed, upset, or bored.
Thanks for sharing 10218! Yes - these are big time triggers. Have you also observed the opposite? Like moods or emotional states where you don't smoke or don't even think about it?
... or let me ask a different question: What could you do other than smoking that would help you deal with these negative feelings? Anything that worked for you in the past?
Sorry guys, I've got to run. I'll be traveling for the next couple of weeks so my colleague Dr. Danielle Ramo will take over and hold office hours. Have a great time and see you later!
Stress, I smoke because of bad anxiety and when I'm stressed out and it helps
That's why I do it.
I literally did not a get a notification from you Johannes Thrul.  I'm so sorry!
I always get the urge to smoke every few hours whether i'm in a good mood or not.  I've always thought exercising helped me when I was feeling down, which in turn helps me to smoke less.

#15: What strategy do you plan to use when you do decide to quit smoking? Will you use any nicotine replacement therapies (like patch or gum)? Medication? Cold turkey? Counseling? Share your plan of action and see if any other group members are on the same page! #beingconscious
I'm thinking of weaning off.  If that doesn't work I'll quit cold turkey.
Replace it with working out, and slowly leaning myself off, cold turkey hasn't worked in the past for mw

I tried replacing with the patch but it didn't really help, I think I'm just gonna quit cold turkey and luckily I've put my del in an invite meant where not many people smoke, and it's actually a hassle to smoke. Fingers crossed it will wok
As of now im weaning on to vapor and then weaning down on the nicotine level
I also thought about switching to ecigs or a cape where you can control the amount of nicotine, but I need to make sure I can distract myself with a healthy addiction when I want to smoke
I quit cold turkey as of yesterday lets see where this goes :/
I want to try vaping instead of smoking.
#13: Do you know anyone who has died from a tobacco-related disease? How did their death affect your own smoking? Post and share your experiences. #reflection
Not sure what its called but my grandfather has a hole in his throat and had to press it to talk from cancer it worries me that I can't break the habit and will end up like that
Actually no not that I remember
I am studying to become an oncologist, and I have met many people with lung cancer. They're the reason I'm quitting.
No one I know died from a tobacco related disease, but my grandma was always on an oxygen tank.  She still smoked even then.
I know of many people but none of them were close to me so I can't say it had a big effect on me
Thank you for sharing.
#14: On a scale of 1-10 (with 10 being most important), how important is it to you to quit smoking for good? #beingconscious
I'd put it at a 7-8
Probably a 5 right now but in the long run an 8 or 9 eventually
Solid 8
Probably a 7.
Anywhere from 7-10

data.description: Hi everyone, the next Q&A session will be on Wednesday. See you!

data.message: #12: Did you know that the number of non-smokers affected by second hand smoke is more than double the number of actual smokers in the U.S.? Who is affected by your second hand smoke?. #smokingaffectsall
Mainly my coworkers and my boyfriend (although he smokes too)
My fiancee and daughter, very rarely tho
I don't really know, I never smoke indoors in the presence of non smokers.

I avoid smoking around people who don't smoke. I feel like I get second hand smoke from my boyfriend because he smokes more than I do and when he isn't smoking, he's getting mine in the car. We both want to quit
Friends, I try not to smoke around people who don't as respect but people can always be affected

#11: Everyone wants to know whether electronic cigarettes can help smokers quit. Unfortunately, studies are showing that they are not any more effective than a placebo. So health professionals still recommend using well-studied strategies like counseling or nicotine replacement therapies (patch, gum) when you’re ready to quit. #ecig
This doesn't surprise me honestly.
But i think the important question is - are they any healthier?
I wonder who funds these studies. Also, I don't think ecigs have been mass marketed for long enough to produce any longitudinal data.

Yes I am more interested in seeing the long term health effects of E Cigsbecause a large part of quitting is also just purely mental, and if E Cigs were confirmed safe I would probably have a much easier time switching and eventually quitting with that method. I got really close to quitting doing it that way once but we lost the pen :/

#8: Here are some things to help you maintain your awesome physique when you stop smoking. Which one seems the most helpful? #balance • Make sure you have a well-balanced diet• Chew sugarless gum when you want something sweet• Eat slowly• Plan healthy, low-fat and low-calorie snacks into your day• Watch portion sizes• Read food labels
Well balanced diet seem to have the better affect. U can eat extremely fatty foods slowly and still gain a lot of weight
Portion size is a big thing for me. Anyone can eat "healthy" but if someone is have a stick of celery with 20 nuggets 4 sauces and 2 double check burgers it's not making any difference.
I agree with your comment on portion size, I tend to have very small healthy meals frequently, but when my discipline cracks I fill up to the brim with junk food

All of the above.  For me, the biggest things will be using gum to occupy time and portion control.  I already read food labels to avoid processed or sugary foods and I do my best to eat healthy.  I just eat a lot in one sitting.  I already know I'm going to eat more once I decide to quit smoking.
I think it's not necessarily what you eat but how much of it you eat

I don't buy into the typical recommended food plate here... fats and oils should be a bigger category because if you are eating the right kind of fats and oils it can do amazing things for your body! I also don't eat much dairy at all! I avoid dairy whenever I can. I'm not lactose intolerant, but my boyfriend is, and I just feel like Almond milk is a lot healthier and easier to digest. Plus, my dentist told me that by drinking 1 glass of almond milk per day, I am preventing osteoporosis and keeping my teeth strong moreso than regular cow milk. I think the most important part of your diet is keeping preservatives, artificial colors and flavors, and fake sugar out of your food. From there, your body will help itself regulate. Naturally, your body is attracted to foods with high protein. Smoothies are great! I don't think my diet would change much other than I'd probably eat a bit more if I quit cigarettes.
Glad to see that many of you support a healthy lifestyle!
A well balanced diet

#9: Research shows that emphasizing the benefits of quitting over the drawbacks helps smokers quit their habit for good. Try your hand at making a negative a positive. What’s your comeback for this drawback? #balance
The withdrawl symptoms will be better than the way my body feels while smoking.  (Nauseous, weak, headache)
Being able to breathe is more important.
Would u prefer lung Cancer? IdK if that would b a valid answer to  this question
Focusing on benefits instead of drawbacks would give me Kore motivation and possibly be able to quit
By quitting for good, you only experience withdrawal once
They are temporary, and compared to cancer treatment, much less to go through and much less pain
Awesome comebacks! :D

#10: Remember Drawback #1 ("I don't want to have withdrawal symptoms") from yesterday’s post? Which one of our following comebacks works for you? #balance • Some withdrawal symptoms are actually signs that my body is healing• I may be coughing more because the cilia (hair-like structures that line my lungs and clean the air I breathe) that were paralyzed by the cigarette smoke are starting to work again, which makes me temporarily cough more• I may have tingling in my arms and legs because my circulation is improving
I'd go with the first
I always get a gnarly cough whenever I quit, all the garbage coming back out and stuff. But I guess I prefer a functional ciliary escalator.

"Some withdrawal symptoms are actually signs that my body is healing" I am a believer in this because when I was younger and in Karate, they always told us during the burnout workouts (push ups, jump burpies, crunches etc til you pass out basically!) That the pain we were experiencing was the pain leaving our body
All of them, honestly.  The first and second are more relevant to me.
Hi everyone and welcome to TSP! I am available for the next hour. Let me know if you have any questions! #TDII
What, in your opinion, are the most helpful things'll quit smoking? Also, I'm 10245 nice to meet you.

Hi 10245 - nice to meet you, too! That’s the million dollar question :) There are several aspects to it: 1. I would recommend to pick a quit day and following through with it. 2. Get support from family/friends/colleagues. 3. Learn new skills and alternative behaviors for your high risk situations. 4. Depending on how much you smoke, I would definitely recommend that you consider trying some form of nicotine replacement therapy – we know that using these can dramatically decrease your cravings and withdrawal and increase your chances to quit for good. 5. Be prepared for relapse or difficult situations (e.g., alcohol, being around other smokers, stress, etc.). I know this sounds like a lot, but we will cover each of these aspects more in depth over the next weeks. How does this sound? Anything there you think may be useful?

1. Do you recommend quitting cold turkey or weaning off?2. What's the best form of nicotine replacement?  I tried the gum and hated it.  I tried the ecig but it just made me want to smoke cigarettes (I love the taste of tobacco.)3.  As someone who is very addicted to cigarettes, do you think I would be able to stick to smoking only when I drink?  Or do you think that will just make me smoke again?  I drink about once a week, probably more now that it's summer, but during the school year once a week or less.
10218 - how much do you currently smoke?
All of it I found very helpful! Thank you
I smoke about a half a pack a day as of right now.

OK 10218 - I think with 10 cig/day you could still consider quitting without any nicotine replacement, even though replacement is going to make coping with urges and withdrawal easier. If you decide to do so, you may want to try the patch as an option. Another avenue may be to gradually reduce the number of cigs you smoke every day. Some things you could try there: Pick certain cigarettes you want to eliminate (e.g. the first or last one each day, a cigarette after a meal), you could also think about declaring smoke free zones to get you to smoke less (e.g. stop smoking in your car). Yet another way would be to gradually increase the time interval between cigarettes. What you are willing to try is really up to you – I simply want to give you comprehensive information so you can make an informed decision.

That's all I can ask for :) i think those suggestions are very helpful.  I was smoking less when I chose which cigarettes i needed the most and which ones I could live without.  Glad you're here!  If I have any more questions I'll let you know.
Sure you're welcome 10218! Which option do you think could work best for you?

I think a combination of making places smoke free and picking certain cigarettes to eliminate.  And something that you sort of mentioned but not quite, if I want a cigarette I could wait 10 minutes and see if I still want one then, eventually making the time intervals longer.
That's a great idea 10218 - most smoking urges only last 5 minutes or at least get a lot better quite quickly. So I definitely recommend trying what you propose. You are already an expert :)
Also establishing smokefree places sounds very good!
My car will be the hardest, but i know it will be the best place to make that rule.

Yes, I agree - you may want to think about giving your car a proper cleanup, so it doesn't smell like smoke anymore and getting rid of your smokes, lighters, etc. in your car. That will make it easier. What else could you do while your in the car to distract yourself when you're craving a smoke?
Probably chew some gum.  Chewing on a pen might work but that's bad for my teeth (albeit not as bad as smoking)
Agreed :)  Those are great ideas. You could also consider toothpicks or hard candy.
OK, i recently picked up vaping, in the past 3 day, and I've almost dropped cigs completely, are there a lot of known health risks to vapes at this point?

Hi 10222 - glad you're here. First off, it's great that you were able to reduce the number of cigs you smoke so drastically. Great question about e-cigs. The problem with e-cigs is that there is no clear data up to now showing that they really help smokers quit. Also, they are not regulated by the FDA, which means that it is unclear what is in them. For all we know, they may still be harmful to your health, even though I think it's fair so say that they are probably a lot safer than regular cigs. I would recommend using nicotine replacement therapy over e-cigs: gum, patch, inhaler (prescription), or lozenge (prescription). Also, other prescription medication like zyban or chantix can be effective, but you have to talk to your doctor first to get a prescription. What you are willing to try is really up to you – I simply want to give you comprehensive information so you can make an informed decision... and again I think it's great that you reduced your number of cigs!

Ok, I'll try some of those, most of em I have tried but they didnt give, I guess the mental satisfaction of the gestures of the habit, plan I have now is to use different levels of nicotine to tapper myself off nicotine completely
I went fro a pack to 1.5 packs a day to 1 cigs a day literally over night
I think that's a great idea, 10222 and we'll certainly support you as best we can!
Sorry, I've got to run. See you next week!

#7: Weight gain is one of the top concerns for almost every smoker. We’ve made a list of some tips that can help keep your weight on track while you quit. Pick the one sounds good to you. How could you implement it into your life? #balance • Go for a walk, swim, bike ride or any exercise you enjoy• Find small ways to be more active, like taking the stairs instead of the elevator or parking a little farther away• Find alternatives to snacking, like calling a friend• Drink some extra water
I have already began drinking extra water, I don't drink near as much coke as I used to, so I guess that's the one I'd choose
I think this summer I'm gonna try to ride my bike every day.
I replace water with juice and pop even though I hardly drink pop and I have lost 15+ pounds in the last 2 months just by reducing portion size of food I've eaten
I definitely plan on running again, it'll be a good distraction from smoking, and a good way to stay fit. Killing two birds with one stone, maybe even more birds
Going on walks might make me want to smoke, but running wouldn't.  Drinking lots of water would help.  Not snacking would be the hardest part.

Honestly I could stand to gain a few pounds. I have been a little underweight most of my life due to low blood pressure and high metabolism that runs in my family. Never been concerned about my weight other than wanting to gain a couple pounds! Not only that, but outside of smoking cigarettes, I try my best to be a healthy person. I only eat preservative free food and organic when I can. I seldom ever eat fast food, why pay $5 at Taco Bell for crap when you can spend $8 at the hot bar in Whole Foods and get a pound of whatever food you want! and it is so much better! So weight gain is and has never been a factor in my smoking. If anything, I would welcome the better appetite because sometimes I have trouble with that. I am coming up to 2 years in my grief so the gut-wrenching depression every single day has thankfully subsided and I am in the process of returning to my "New Normal". I hope that reducing my smoking habit is part of that!
