data.description: Hi everyone and welcome to the group. On Wednesday, I will be holding the first "The Doctor Is In" session from 5-6 PM (Pacific Time). You can ask me everything you want to know around smoking, quitting, and the Tobacco Status Project.

data.message: #6: What would be the best-case scenario if you quit smoking? #balance
Much less health risk.

As.doctors have told me we pay for there vacations, if I stopped smoking and out that money aside I could go on a 1500-2000 vacation at least, every year along with feeling much healthier having your senses develop again and decrease risks of cancer, heart disease, etc.

I would love to stop smoking for at least 1 year before planning to try for another baby. I lost my son to SIDS 2 years ago, believe me I have been guilted by the smoking. I did not smoke during my pregnancy, but I smoked 2-3 cigs a day while breast feeding.... :( My son died at 2 months 2 weeks. I never smoked anywhere near him, I would wash my hands, brush my teeth, and I had a special overcoat I would only wear while smoking so that my regular clothes would not smell.... but apparently wasn't enough. Still don't know how I feel about cigs in relation to SIDS. I have been told by other moms that my smoking was not related to my son's death. But SIDS is so unknown how could we know for sure? The guilt will always be there. I just know I don't want to be smoking with my next child. I don't want to take ANY risks :(

The unfortunate part about it all is that his death is what bumped me back up to smoking from 2-3 cigs to 6-7 cigs in a day. Even the police who came the day he died (we had called 911 because we woke up to him unresponsive. This is apparently common for SIDS to wake in the morning to find an unresponsive baby...:( ) the POLICE BOUGHT ME A PACK OF CIGS. It was a nice gesture of them, I was grateful at the time, but it may have increased my need for cigs because obviously that was the most traumatic day in my entire life. I would never want to re live that horrible day, June 7th 2013. But trust me, losing my son has not made quitting any easier...
I would have 20 more bucks a week, and therefore would have more money.  My health would improve and I would be able to breathe better.  I might even convince myself to start singing again.
It'd be a combo of the health improvement, money saved, and lowered risk to my family

Welcome to the Tobacco Status Project! Thank you for joining us -- we're so excited to have you here. We're going to start posting TOMORROW (Wednesday) at 12 noon PST! Here's how it works:1) We will share one post everyday for 90 days. Remember to turn on your notifications and check this page daily!2) You will earn $1 for commenting on each post, within 24 hours after it was posted. You will receive a gift card for the total amount you've earned at the end of the 90-day program.3) Dr. Johannes Thrul will be joining us for 1 hour each week, during which he will answer any tobacco-related questions, share info and resources, and provide support to our group. Stay tuned for his first session next week!
What time will he be available?
10218, he will schedule his session with your group in advance. The time is typically Wednesday evenings. Thanks for asking!

Thank you for this group, I feel like it's kind of a support group for us smokers who have an interest in quitting and I greatly appreciate having a platform where I can express my feeling about this subject. It's honestly not something a lot of people talk about / want to talk about
Thank you for joining us 10255! We appreciate your feedback!
#1: Share a success that you’ve had in the past. It can be anything from any time. Why did it work? Who helped? #motivation
Got an insulin pump for my type 1 diabetes. My fiance really pushed me to get it. Eventually gave in, and it has really changed my life.

I stopped taking my depression medication.  I had been on it from ages 12 to 18 and my boyfriend pushed me to get off of them.  After a few months of getting used to actually feeling my emotions, I am now happier than ever before.  I learned/am learning how to deal with my emotions in a healthy way, such as exercise, yoga, art, music, etc.
I dropped marijuana completely several months ago, had been smoking it for several yes then my fiancee convinced me to stop for our daughters sake, I quit that day cold turkey
I recently scored quite well on the MCAT. I studied as hard as I possibly could have, with the support of my parents and Grandmother.
Pregnancy is the only time I have successfully quit on a dime cold turkey and not had a problem. I had no desire to smoke, and the smell grossed me out and gave me a headache.
Not sure if it works but it can't hurt...
data.story: 10222 shared Ridwan Kamil's photo to the group: 2014-15 Thinking About Quitting 6.
data.name: Ridwan Kamil
data.description: Selamat pagi warga Bandung, selamat hari #SelasaTanpaRokok. Hayu kita latihan sehari tanpa asap rokok. Saling menghargai dan saling mengingatkan dengan santun.

data.message: No clue that could work going to try it
Its helped me out some actually

It also helps to put things in your mouth, not random things per say, but like a toothpick and a pen, or pencil, it's been proven that half of the addiction I smoking is the pure motion of picking up something and putting it in your mouth. It comes from a biological interest in wanting to taste things from when we are children. Try it.
10222, thank you for sharing this interesting tip! :)

For a while, what worked for me was chewing REGULAR gum, not nicotine, just plain ol gum. Problem with that is I became addiced to the gum! lol! but I guess a sore jaw and some sugar isn't as bad as a cig.
#2: Educate yourself on the smoking rates and laws in your state. Search up “smoking information” and “smoking bans” in your state. Did any of the information surprise you? #smokingaffectsall

Smoking in common work areas is prohibited unless a majority of workers in that area agree to designate it as a smoking area. Smoking is permitted when a majority of workers in an area decide to designate a common work area as a smoking area, unless the employer prohibits it. Did not realize this
I recently came home from school only to find out that I needed to be 21 years old to spend almost $15 on a pack, and that I couldn't smoke in parks or on city property... NYC really took a stand
Damn

The most notable laws I saw in Illinois are as follows:-it's illegal to smoke with a minor in the car-It's illegal to throw cigarette butts on the ground (you will get pulled over and fined)-all colleges in Illinois have banned smoking on school property.  (I know this because my college is starting it in June.)Illinois is cracking down too. Also, 2900 people in Illinois die each year from second-hand smoke.
California has gotten pretty strict about it in recent years
#3: How would you support someone who tells you they want to quit smoking? #motivation
Always talk to them. Distract them from smoking by going on hikes and stuff.
Give them tips and tricks to try and  get rid of the "need" for a cigarette, alternatives ect.
Try to help them keep their mind off of it by going out and doing stuff together, and being there for them when the cravings hit, especially in stressful situations.
Possibly start a system to wear ourselves off of tobacco together. Buddy system works well most of the time.
I would give them as much information as possible about ways to quit.

I would deffinitely never smoke around them, or even mention Tabacco in all it's forms, simply talking about it can be a trigger, but yes I would try and get them to be active, or maybe try and find out why they smoked in the first place, like for me I started smoking out of social enxiety, hard to explain but it is what it is, so for me I could see working on feeling anxious as a very good first step to start quitting, turn off the tap and the flooding stops, then you can start to fix your problem.
As a smoker yourself respect they're trying to quit, I wouldn't smoke in front of them and give them confidence they can quit but if you're still smoking there's not much else you can say

I respect people who quit or are trying to quit. I never offer them cigs and try not to smoke near them. If they ask me for a cig I don't just hand it to them. I ask, "Are you sure? I Thought you were trying to quit" because I would want someone to remind me too. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't.
#5: Many e-cig companies are actually owned by BIG TOBACCO companies. What do you think their motives are? To have you remain a loyal customer? To help you quit smoking? Other ideas? #ecig
Probably to get more people hooked

The ecigs big tobacco companies make are horrible for you.  Many people (at least in my town) buy the ecigs (i think they're called vape pens) with giant batteries and coils with adjustable temps where you drip the liquid in.  They get them online or buy the parts and make it/adjust it themselves.  I rarely see people with the cheap $40 ecigs you buy at a cigarette shop.  We're also lucky to have a smoke shop that makes its own ecig juice and it only has 3 or 4 ingredients.  It's extremely popular in the vaping scene and not that expensive.  I worry about Big Tobacco taking control of ecig production because they don't care about the customer, they just want money (like any mega corp) and will use cheap, toxic products.
I've heard e cigs are way worse then actual tobacco and they want the profit for their company

I feel like they brand them differently so they continue to control the tobacco
icotine market no matter what they choose to smoke.

All the articles I've read saying ecigs are harmful are about the ones owned by big tobacco and/or are the cheap kinds that look like pens or cigars, and I'm pretty sure it's about what's in the liquid.  I'm no expert though, I'll admit.

It's the same principal as a fake competitor in the economic system, a big company isn't moving products fast enough so they create a " competitor" so now people have two options but the money is still going back to the same place. And as for the keeping you a customer YESSSSS very much so, everyone who has smoked an e-cig knows that there is nothing that compares to a real cigaret, even the self rolled ones, so people buy the e-cig, try it out, and then realize why they smoked cigarets so yeah it's a way to keep you hooked to the old style. Besides that's what they want you to stick to, they already have all the setups to produce Tabacco, if they needed to change everything to supply the world with e-cigs it would be a loss in one way or another, and we all know they cant possibly afford that. Haha
These are all great points! Thanks for discussing! :)

Putting crap on the market could definitely be part of a plan to turn public interest away from cigarette alternatives. Also, ecigs can get you really hooked on nicotine but without the MAOi's found in tobacco, meaning that the companies have two addicting products, and the one they're most heavily invested in has further reinforcement for the addiction.
I don't trust most of the tobacco companies

Good afternoon, TSP members! Our group has officially been launched today! We'd like to remind you that this secret group is a great place to share your thoughts and engage in conversation. Please feel free to like or respond to each others' comments and share any relevant content of your own.To begin, let's take a moment to introduce ourselves and get to know each other a little better. Feel free to share with us:• Where you come from• Anything about your smoking (how much, how often, when you first started, etc.)• What you hope to gain from participating in the Tobacco Study ProjectThank you! We're so excited to have you here.

Pell city Alabama I smoke about half a pack a day, depending on the stupidity of my co workers. I started smoking 10yrs ago at the age of 10, my cousin stole some from his dad and we have been heavy smokers since.For a while I was smoking up to 3packs a day, and ive cut back a lot so with this I hope to be able to get tips and cut back completely.

I'm from Bloomington IL.I smoke about a half a pack a day.  Recently I've started smoking two or three at a time.  I've been smoking since I was 14, regularly since I was 15.  I've switched to additive free cigarettes because regular ones make me feel sick.  The two kinds I smoke are Kentucky's Best (5.79/pack) and American Spirits (8/pack).  Over the past year breathing has become difficult.  I used to be a singer but I stopped after an embarassing performance where I ran out of breath in the middle of a song and haven't done it since.  I would love to quit completely or maybe stick to when I'm drinking.
Omg, American spirits are like 3.20/pack here...
What!!! That's insane.
Like no one really smokes em so they cheap, most expensive we got is Marlboro special blend and its abt 5.60/pack..... This is y ppl retire and move south

Haha, I've definitely considered moving south once I'm done with college...or west.  My mom's from the south so I go down to tennessee, south carolina, and alabama on a fairly regular basis.  It's all beautiful.
Bama is the place to b

Lima ohio, Smoke just over a pack a day.My first cigarette was at age 11, by 15 I smoke regularly. By 16 I started smoking a pack a day. In January I quit for 3 weeks cold turkey. A stressful home situation got the best of me and I started again. I smoke pyramid lights about $4.54 a pack here. It's one of the cheaper routes in ohio. I want to quit smoking for 2 reasons. One being my fiance constantly bringing it up since I started back up. Two is due to my diabetes. It takes a harsh toll on my body. I can be as active as I want to be. I'm sure it will be a pleasure to participate in this program with you all.

Kalamazoo Michigan, My first cigerattes was around age 13, started smoking regularly at age 15/16 and now I smoke almost a pack a day and sometimes more, I'm addicted to the motions of smoking a cigarettes which I heard is the reason a lot of smokers smoke, I don't think I'm ready to quit but I would definetly like to be able to slow down

I am from the SF Bay Area in California. I was born here and have lived here my whole 23 year life. I have a beautiful Angel Son named Miles, forever 2 months 2 weeks old. March 25th 2013 - June 7th 2013. I have a kitty girl named Tikal who is going to be 12 this year. I have been smoking on and off for most of my life. My mother is a "religious" smoker, she smokes a pack of maraboro reds every single day, and has done so my entire life. As far as I know, she did reduce her smoking greatly while pregnant with me, but still smoked occassionally. I dont know how long after giving birth to me she continued, but by the time I was a young child I remember her in the backyard with her cigarette. In her defense, she never smoked inside until I was 13.  (you have to remember this was back in the late 90's early 00's so there wasn't as much info)I tried my first smoke at 12 years old while my parents were going through a nasty divorce. My dad and I had a terrible relationship but I was stuck living with him due to the divorce arrangement at the time, and after a fight with him, I took a cigarette butt I had taken from my mother's ash tray one day out of curiosity, and lit it up. The stress from being angry with my dad went away and that is how I became hooked. Luckily at the time, being 12, I wasn't able to get more cigs. I still smoked cigs here and there throughout my teens but not very often at all. On average, maybe 10 cigs in a -year-. But once I was 18, and at the time living with my mother, I began smoking again. Me and her were not getting along, I broke up with my fiance that I was supposed to be married to, I went through a bout of homelessness. It was during this time my smoking was at its worst.I smoked at least a pack a day, sometimes 2 packs in a day of Camel Crush, Pall Mall, Marlboro, and L&M during this time period from 18-19. Thankfully my life slowed down and got less chaotic for a while right before I turned 20. I found a place to live with family friends, and got with my current boyfriend Damian in 2012. I reduced my smoking and switched to American Spirits. I made the change because I felt like by switching to a natural cigarette, it was a healthier choice. I still only ever smoke American Spirits when I do smoke cigarettes. I refuse to even try anything else. I don't like the way other cigs smell. I feel like I can smell the chemicals.Even if American Spirits aren't healthier for me, I just feel like they are better choice for me at this time. I smoke less of them, I could never smoke a whole pack in a day. They last longer, burn slower, and according to the box, they seem to at least care about the environment. I started to quit smoking on my own before I found out I was pregnant with my son in June 2012. I started quitting because they didn't taste right and didn't feel right. Then I found out I was pregnant and I quit instantly without any problems. The smell of cigs began to piss me off and give me a headache throughout my whole pregnancy, so I did not smoke nor stand around anyone who was smoking.I had an extremely stressful birth process. I was a week late and had to be induced. After 38 hours of labor, my placenta ruptured and they had to do an Emergency C Section. I almost died and so did my son. My son was not breathing for the first 2-5 minutes of his life. By a miracle he started crying and was fine. He passed all his screening tests and I had my baby boy with me. Unfortunately we had to stay in the hospital for 4 days because of my c section. I was going stir-crazy in there, what with all the nurses bugging me here and there, I had an allergic reaction to my IV, it was just hell. Couldn't wait to get home.Sadly the anticipation gave me enough time and stress and anger to want another cig. So I started my mildest smoking regimen ever, only 1 cig in the morning, 1 cig at late evening, and 1 cig in the middle of the night. I timed them to be away from times my son breast fed. After my son passed away I have tried to quit a few times. The longest I have quit in the past couple years since 2013 was 2 months. Most recently I quit for 8 days because I had to have my wisdom teeth removed. It was challenging but I was able to quit. It probably would have stuck if it weren't for a bunch of family emergencies coming up right after I had my surgery that involved me being up for over 24 hours, and I was so worn out and tired that I broke down and started smoking. That was in March, and I have been smoking ever since. Sorry about the long post I just figured the more info you have, the better. Thanks for reading <3

#4: For any of you who aren’t sure what an e-cig is, take a look at this FDA page explaining what they are and some of the controversy surrounding their regulation. If you were a minor, do you think an e-cig would be more appealing and “safer” to try than a traditional cigarette? #beingconscious http://www.fda.gov/newsevents/publichealthfocus/ucm172906.htm

To a minor, ecigs are more appealing, they get to "smoke" without as much risk of caught due to the smell on clothing or breath. They are easy to hide. And kids can get away with them at school if they are smart about it.

10222, I agree to an extent. But I feel as if some of our youth like the idea of breaking the law or just the general feeling of being rebellious. I was somewhat of a "troublemaker" when I was younger and cigarettes were my first way of acting out.
Same here but the ecigs were an easier way

E-cigs were very appealing to me when I was a minor.  I always wanted to get the thick smoke and blow o-rings or do other smoke tricks.  I always believed it was safer without looking at the facts (which there aren't enough of.)  I bought my first e-cig when I was 16 and I puffed on it for hours at a time, only stopping when I got lightheaded.  The thing is, it never stopped me from smoking cigarettes because I never used it properly.  In fact, I bet it caused me to smoke more because my body got used to higher levels of niccotine. I like the e-cig juice you can buy online or in a smoke shop (my local smoke shop makes their own) because they only have three or four ingredients.  I think if used properly, e-cigs are great for people who really do want an alternative.  The problem is that most people (based on my perception, which is quite limited) don't use it that way.
I tried using them to quit, never felt the same or did the job. They look cool and have some perks, but don't really satisfy a cigarette craving.
Wow I actually had a friends try and warn me about them but I never listened, eventually I just lost my e-cig. I'm glad it's lost. I wonder if they have one for the vape pens
They taste nasty and have made me sick over regular cigerattes I don't trust the chemicals in e cigs to be safer
Thank you for sharing!

I'm still unsure how I feel about e cigs. On one point, since they are smoke-free, they don't have the same carcinogens that cig smoke has, but on another point, the long term effects of e cigs have not been studied. So we don't know for sure if they are safer
